bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Founded in 1988, Visual AIDS is the only contemporary arts organization fully committed to raising AIDS awareness and creating dialogue around HIV issues today, by producing and presenting visual art projects, exhibitions, public forums, and publicationsâ€”while assisting artists living with HIV/AIDS. We are committed to preserving and honoring the work of artists with HIV/AIDS and the artistic contributions of the AIDS movement.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Institutional Records collection consists of materials relating to the organizational history of Visual AIDS. The collection consists of papers, photographs, 35mm slides, exhibition materials, publications, promotional materials, periodicals, correspondence, buttons, collectible cards, condoms, press clippings, printed artworks, broadsides, postcards, and ephemera.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials in this collection are arranged by subject. Within subject, the folders are arranged chronologically by year and then alphabetically.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This finding aid was prepared by Jacs Rodriguez in 2024. This finding aid was made possible in part by a grant from the Documentary Heritage Program of the New York State Archives, a program of the State Education Department.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: A collection of 53.75 linear feet of Visual AIDS institutional records were donated to NYU Fales Library and Special Collections in late June 2017. The finding aid for that collection can be found here: https://findingaids.library.nyu.edu/fales/mss_503/

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Administrative Files series contains materials pertaining to the general operation and history of Visual AIDS outside of the specific categories represented by other series. This includes materials associated with organizational history, planning and development, general information sheets and promotional materials, and press about Visual AIDS as a whole.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These materials include papers, press clippings, correspondence, exhibition materials, promotional materials, buttons, ephemera, personnel files, and photographs. These materials are dated 1989-2012.

did.unittitle: Visual AIDS Material in Exhibitions and Collections

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: In 1994, the artist Frank Moore and arts writer David Hirsh formed the Archive Project to protect the legacies of artists who were being lost to the AIDS crisis. Moore and Hirsh were joined by Roberto Juarez, Sur Rodney (Sur), Eric Rhein, Geoff Hendricks, Ken Chu, and David Cabrera in this endeavor, and the group soon merged with Visual AIDS. Artists were solicited to join the archive through flyers, posters, and personal outreach. Volunteer photographers would visit artists in their homes or studios to document and catalog their artwork, providing the artist with a copy of the slides and depositing a copy into the archive. Artists (and the friends and families of deceased artists) also contributed press clippings, resumes, exhibition cards and other biographical materials to their artist files. The collection that has developed out of this ongoing endeavor is now known as the Visual AIDS Artist Files collection.

The Artist Registry is an online repository containing artwork by over 970 HIV+ artists. Created in November 2012 with digitized slides from the Visual AIDS Artist Files, the Registry is continuously growing, allowing anyone who self-identifies as an artist living with HIV to create a profile.
Materials pertaining to the history and development of both the Archive Project and the Artist Registry are included in this sub-series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to the Archive Project contain correspondence, promotional materials, exhibition materials, press clippings, photographs, development materials, periodicals, and papers. These materials are dated 1989-2005.

did.unittitle: Library Collection Development and Donation Solicitations
Estate Project for Artists with AIDS

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Since 1992, Visual AIDS has commissioned artists to create print projects that utilize artistic strategies to share information about the HIV and AIDS crisis. First conceived as a part of Day Without Art, the first Visual AIDS broadsides were intentionally easy to photocopy and distributed without copyright to encourage organizations to reproduce and disseminate them. In the decades since, the form of these print projects has expanded to include stickers, buttons, and larger newsprint broadsides.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Visual AIDS Broadsides and Print Projects include copies of broadsides, production materials, correspondence, stickers, buttons, condoms, playing cards, collectible items, and promotional materials. These materials are dated 1992-2022.
The materials in this sub-series are primarily arranged by artist or creator name.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: From 2010 to 2019, Visual AIDS produced Play Smart safer sex kits containing artist-created trading cards, condoms, and lube. The trading cards included straightforward information about HIV testing, pre and post exposure prophylaxis, and other harm reduction strategies. Play Smart kits were distributed freely in bars, queer spaces, and art institutions. The project was developed in conversation with Dr. Demetre Daskalakis at The Men's Sexual Health Project (M*SHP). Organizations like Streetwise & Safe, Sero Project, GMHC, SRLP, and Callen-Lorde collaborated in developing and distributing Play Smart nationally.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Play Smart campaigns include correspondence, press clippings, promotional materials, event programs, and press clippings. These materials are dated 2005-2019.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: In 1989, in response to the worsening AIDS crisis and coinciding with the World Health Organization's second annual World AIDS Day on December 1, Visual AIDS organized the first Day Without Art. A committee of art workers (curators, writers, and art professionals) sent out a call for "mourning and action in response to the AIDS crisis" that would celebrate the lives and achievements of lost colleagues and friends; encourage caring for all people with AIDS; educate diverse publics about HIV; and call for a cure. More than 800 arts organizations, museums and galleries throughout the U.S. participated by shrouding artworks and replacing them with information about HIV and safer sex, locking their doors or dimming their lights, and producing exhibitions, programs, readings, memorials, rituals, and performances. Visual AIDS coordinated this network mega-event by producing a poster and handling promotion and press relations.

During the early nineties, as artists became more intimately involved with the group, Visual AIDS initiated numerous projects that included: A Night Without Light (the dimming of the New York skylight); Electric Blanket (a nationwide outdoor slide projection with text and images); Positive Actions (an exhibition-competition for a television PSA held simultaneously in three NYC venues); the Broadside Project (distribution of copyright-free text and images by well-known artists targeted to specific audiences); and ambitious media collaborations, including AIDS Timeline by Group Material and national televised events. Artists created many of the most moving actions, including Robert Farber's audio work "Every Ten Minutes". By the mid-90's, Day Without Art attracted more than 8000 participants throughout the world.

Since 2010, Visual AIDS has worked with artists and filmmakers to internationally distribute videos to museums, art institutions, schools and AIDS organizations for Day Without Art. Since 2014, Visual AIDS has commissioned and distributed a video program for Day With(out) Art, coordinating screenings at over 100 venues around the world.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Day Without Art contain exhibition announcements, photographs, 35mm slides, correspondence, promotional materials, exhibition planning materials, press clippings, periodicals, exhibition programs, and publications. These materials are dated 1989-2022.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: After the founding of the Archive Project in 1994, Visual AIDS began to organize exhibitions to present work by artists living with HIV. The organization's first exhibitions focused solely on artists represented in its archive. In the late 1990s, Visual AIDS exhibition program shifted towards curated group exhibitions that examine the deep cultural history of the AIDS crisis and contemporary issues around HIV/AIDS. These exhibitions have included both HIV positive and HIV negative artists. Guest curators have included Julia Bryan-Wilson, Dean Daderko, Sur Rodney (Sur), Jean Carlomusto, Alexandra Juhasz, Hugh Ryan, Josh Lubin Levy & Ricardo Montez. Visual AIDS has never operated its own exhibition space, instead partnering with galleries, non-profits, and community spaces to mount exhibitions. Exhibition partners have included La MaMa Galleria, The 8th Floor, Printed Matter, Artists Space, The Painting Center, Real Art Ways, Boston Center for the Arts, Fales Library and Special Collections, Aljira, P.S. 122, Transformer Gallery, Elizabeth Foundation for the Arts, and MoCADA, among others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Visual AIDS exhibitions contain exhibition announcements, exhibition planning materials, promotional materials, correspondence, photographs, and press clippings. These materials are dated 1989-2021.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Visual AIDS produces numerous public events and programs, often partnering with other organizations and museums. The Public Programs series contains announcements, handouts, and internal documents related to panels, book fairs, and other public events that Visual AIDS organized or participated in.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Visual AIDS Public Programs include exhibition and program announcements, promotional materials, planning materials, ephemera, and event programs. These materials are dated 2008-2022.

did.unittitle: "Festival for Ideas for the New City" Materials
"Radically Gay: The Life & Visionary Legacy of Harry Hay" Materials

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Visual AIDS's publishing program produces books that highlight underknown artists and preserve legacies that might otherwise be lost. Publication types include monographs, exhibition catalogs, and the "Duets: In Conversation" series. Duets pairs artists, activists, writers, and thinkers in dialogues about their creative practices and current social issues related to HIV/AIDS.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Visual AIDS publications contain planning materials, proofs, promotional materials, and published comic books. These materials are dated 1995-2021.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: In 1991 a group of artists known as the Visual AIDS Artists' Caucus came together to create a meaningful symbol to show support and compassion for those with AIDS and their caregivers at the height of the crisis. They created what was titled "The Ribbon Project," better known today simply as the Red Ribbon. Through a series of meetings in April and May of 1991, the Red Ribbon was born. The color red was chosen for its "connection to blood and the idea of passion - not only anger but love".

Visual AIDS partnered with Broadway Cares and Equity Fights AIDS in June 1991 to adorn guests and presenters at the 45th Annual Tony Awards. The red ribbon quickly became renowned as an international symbol of AIDS awareness, and has been worn at the Oscars, Emmys, and Grammys; celebrities, musicians, athletes, artists, and politicians have worn the ribbon on talk shows, TV programs, movies, political conventions, sporting events, and music videos.

Today the red ribbon is an internationally recognized symbol of AIDS awareness and a design icon. It has led the way for many other color ribbons and awareness projects. Unlike some other commercial marketing campaigns, the red ribbon originally evolved as an artists/activist project and it has never been copyrighted.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to the Red Ribbon Project include production materials, photographs, promotional materials, press clippings, correspondence, loan agreements, and exhibition announcements. This material is dated 1991-2021.

did.unittitle: Cooper Hewitt Design Museum Exhibition Announcements

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Benefit Events series contains announcements, documentation, and internal records related to Visual AIDS fundraising events. Since 2006, Visual AIDS's primary benefit event has been the Visual AIDS Vanguard Awards (VAVA Voom), a gala that recognizes the achievements and contributions of individuals who strengthen the cultural history of art, AIDS and activism in our community.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Visual AIDS benefits include exhibition announcements, invitations, correspondence, advertisements, press clippings, and planning materials. These materials are dated 1998-2018.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Visual AIDS published limited edition prints by renowned contemporary artists as part of its fundraising efforts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to benefit prints include promotional materials, correspondence, press clippings, and planning materials. These materials are dated 2012-2022.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Since 1998, Visual AIDS has produced the annual Postcards From the Edge exhibition and benefit. For this fundraiser, Visual AIDS solicits original, postcard-sized works on paper by established and emerging artists.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials pertaining to Postcards from the Edge contain promotional materials and exhibition announcements. These materials are dated 1998-2022.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Collected HIV/AIDS Historical Materials series has materials related to HIV/AIDS art and activism that have been collected by Visual AIDS staff but not produced by the organization or its artist members. The materials include those produced by individuals as well as by other HIV/AIDS organizations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials in this series include photographs, 35mm slides, press clippings, ephemera, collectible materials, printed artworks, and exhibition materials. These materials are dated 1988-2020.
